Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Solar CO2 Reduction (SCO2RE) with Non-Innocent Ligand Transition Metal Photocatalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jonathan Rochford of UMass Boston seeks mechanistic insight into the solar driven production of chemical feedstocks from carbon dioxide. One such product, carbon monoxide, is a valuable precursor towards further reduced carbon-based fuels as well as syngas, a staring material used in the petrochemical industry. There remain major obstacles to overcome before such multi-electron photocatalysis can be efficiently utilized from single photon initiated processes in molecular systems. In this context, Professor Rochford and his research group designs rhenium(I)carbonyl systems with non-innocent ligands that are capable of efficient light harvesting in the visible spectrum while also displaying strong potential as carbon dioxide reduction photocatalysts. While rhenium is a precious metal and its supply is limited, this research project repeatedly reuses tiny amounts of the metal to create significant amounts of desired product, making the overall effort more environmentally friendly than current techniques for the production of fuels and industrial feedstocks. This research is considered under the "SusChEM" initiative as it converts a non-petroleum based feedstock (carbon dioxide) into useful carbon-containing materials. By combining a rational program of synthesis, electrochemistry, and photophysical analyses, a greater understanding of design strategies towards solar carbon dioxide conversion is developed.

Mimicking natural photosynthesis by harvesting the sun's energy towards a sustainable process for fuel production represents one of the grand challenges of science today. This project aids in further understanding artificial photosynthesis and provides multi-disciplinary training for students at UMass Boston. Furthermore, key concepts and findings of this project are integrated into the undergraduate curriculum at UMass Boston to educate future generations of scientists on the importance of utilizing solar energy as our society works towards a sustainable and greener future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this award was to investigate mechanisms for the harvesting and storage of solar energy in the form of chemical bonds via photocatalytic carbon dioxide conversion. In addition to using manganese and nickel as cheaper and more abundant alternatives to traditional rhenium based catalytic systems, this project has succeeded in developing novel ligand platforms for the development of new generation carbon dioxide reduction catalysts by two strategies. Firstly, to optimize the demanding thermodynamics and kinetics of carbon dioxide reduction, second coordination sphere sites on the ligand were established to provide a strategic platform for the shuttling of protons to the activated carbon dioxide substrate enabling proton-coupled C-OH bond cleavage (the rate-determining step) and evolution of carbon monoxide. Secondly, ligand systems were designed which participate in the catalytic cycle as “co-factors” by providing electron equivalents via redox non-innocence. In this case, the one-electron reduced reactive intermediates actively involved in the catalytic reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide were investigated by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) experiments. Here the extent of ligand contribution in the mechanism of electron-transfer to the transition metal-carbon dioxide adduct was investigated. In total, 2 undergraduate students, 5 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral scholars have directly participated and contributed to this research.

The primary educational goal of this project was to implement a Chemistry-and-Sustainable-Energy (CaSE) study of the undergraduate chemistry curriculum. The principal goal of this educational plan was to expose freshman and senior level undergraduate students at UMB to a fresh perspective on how energy-in-chemistry relates to the real world around us. Freshman students were taught about the advantages of using solar irradiation to drive chemical reactions as well as being introduced to the study and application of the 12 principles of green chemistry. At the senior level, a new sequence of laboratory experiments was designed for chemistry majors to learn about (i) the fundamentals of electrochemistry, via cyclic voltammetry (ii) the application of electrochemical principles for solar-to-electricity conversion, by fabrication and characterization of dye-sensitized solar cells and (iii) solar-to-fuel conversion, utilizing both cobalt mediated electrocatalytic H2 evolution and manganese mediated CO2 reduction. Further to these efforts, the PI has also served of faculty ambassador for the UMass Boston American Chemical Society Undergraduate Student Chapter. In this role the PI has annually served to organize a committee of undergraduate students and supervise them in their running of a wide variety of campus events designed to engage the broader UMass Boston undergraduate community in STEM activites.
